results.title: ECCOS
results.brief_description:
Andrew Norman Wilson is the mastermind behind “ECCOS” — a “six-hour meditation video” featuring slowed-down footage of a gamer beating Ecco the Dolphin on Sega Genesis. Wilson produced the work from an 80-minute clip, to which he added echo filters for both audio and video tracks. The result is nothing short of haunting — a swirling, psychedelic, and slightly ominous collection of pixelated creatures and seascapes, scored to a persistent low hum.

ECCOS is just one part of Wilson’s “Center for Wave Change” — a proposed “experimental philosophical space that focuses on the phenomena of waves.”

Amar Toor, The Verge, 24/05/12

constellations_other.name: The dolphin Constellation
constellations_other.description: This Constellation echoes representations of dolphins across screen media.

results.title: Ecco the Dolphin
results.brief_description: Life was an adventure for Ecco, the young dolphin. The ocean seemed endless with rolling breakers to race through! At high speed Ecco could burst through the waves leaping through the air – almost flying! Until one day, all of that changed. A freak whirlpool of air and water tore the life from Ecco’s home leaving Ecco all alone. Now he must fight to stay alive, while traversing the vast ocean in search of clues that will help him save his family and return them to the bay.

results.title: Eating your heart out [Captioned]
results.creator_credit: Chris Warner, Maureen McCarthy and Trout Films
results.brief_description: Eating your heart out is about food, dieting and obsessional eating, especially as they effect women and girls in western societies. The program looks at four eating disorders: anorexia nervosa; bulimia; obesity; and a condition known as the fat/thin woman. It also examines the wider societal pressures on women that lead to these eating obsessions.

results.title: Eating your heart out
results.creator_credit: Chris Warner, Maureen McCarthy and Trout Films
results.brief_description: A study of food, dieting and obsessional eating especially as they affect women and girls in Western societies. Examines a number of eating disorders such as anorexia nervosa, bulimia, obesity and the condition known as the fat thin woman as well as wider social pressures that lead to obsessions about eating. Narrated by Beverly Dunn, music by Mark McSherry, photographed by Jaems Grant.

results.title: Eating Raoul
results.creator_credit: Paul Bartel, Anne Kimmel, Quartet Films, Quartet, International Classis and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Paul and Mary Bland, an endearingly middle-class couple, want to get out of their swinger-infested apartment building and open a nice little restaurant in the country. However, real estate is expensive and Paul has just lost his job. So, they take out a kinky ad and then knock off the rich swingers who answer it…Enter Raoul.

results.title: Eat your greens
results.brief_description: A poignant short film about the tenuous nature of families, as a husband arrives home to his disgruntled wife whose just about to serve dinner. Cast includes Elizabeth Maywald, Alan Cinis, Lauren and Mark Snell.

results.title: Eat the rich
results.creator_credit: Peter Richardson, Tim Van Rellim and Ironfist Pictures
results.brief_description: From the makers of the “Comic strip” and the “Young Ones”, this black and often tasteless comedy is certain to startle. Alex, a black waiter at a celebrated restaurant for the rich called “Bastards”, is sacked. Determined to wreak revenge, he organises a people’s take over and captures the restaurant. Renaming it “Eat the Rich”, Alex and his friends serve up their own special brand of millionaires mince. Not for the faint-hearted and with a heavy metal soundtrack by Motorhead.

results.title: Eat the peach
results.creator_credit: Peter Ormrod, John Kelleher and Strongbow Productions
results.brief_description: Based on a true story, Peter Ormrod’s tragi-comic tale of aspiring no-hopers follows the misadventures of two Irish villagers, Vinnie (Stephen Brennan) and Arthur (Eamon Mornsey), made unemployed by the closure of a Japanese electronics factory, who take inspiration from an old Elvis movie and blow their redundancy money on building a motorcycle “Wall of Death”. Local fame follows, but will the men have the spirit to survive if their big opening day doesn’t quite live up to their dreams? In the tradition of the Frank Capra genre this film is sure to enchant.
